ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to critically read and analyze world literature.
I learned how to write critically and read closely.
Critical discussions on race, gender, the postcolonial gaze, and the intersections of various class dynamics in world literature. Learned how to close read texts for meaning.

I developed a better understanding of how to do a close reading of a novel and relate the meaning with the larger setting in which the novel was written, like the background of the author of the social and political environment of its place and time of writing.
I learned a lot about world literature and this class opened up my mind to analyzing texts deeper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I appreciated the breadth of material we read and felt like there was enough time to discuss the texts. If Professor Iheka could've banned screens at the beginning of the course I think our class time could've been used more productively.
The class discussions were riveting but the texts could be a little more varied!

Strengths: discussion was challenging and thought-provoking, ideas touched on will continue to stay with me, themes were well-developed over the course of the syllabus, came away with a new understanding of the way world literature is shaped by outside forces

Weaknesses: didnt cover enough of the world. barely any books from Asia, Middle East, South America, etc. reading load was not evenly distributed. basically had to read 150 pages between Tuesday and Thursday. discussions went overtime to the next week, and while valuable, threw the syllabus out of balance, making class a bit less focused since we were basically covering two books each week instead of one.

The discussion was lively and helped me gain new insight into the novels, and I found myself understanding the books differently based on what my peers had to say. However, all we did was write 3 essays and discuss a lot of books, so I found it difficult to stay engaged.

This course was difficult to keep up with. The extensive homework assignments caused me to feel constantly left behind because I rarely was able to finish them. The reading was just far too extensive. However, I was able to learn enough in the class discussions to the point where I was not completely left behind.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would but reluctantly. I took this as a major requirement and I enjoyed reading some of the texts but it felt a little like checking a box which wasn't my intention starting out with the course. Because the people in my seminar were not the most engaged, I struggled to feel motivated in the class. Professor Iheka felt like an easy grader.
Yes! You bond a lot with your classmates and read closely about texts that would not normally appear in a traditional Eurocentric English classroom.

yes, it provided a thorough introduction to various books in the canon of world literature. it challenged me as a student to think about topics of race, class, and gender and the ways various authors subvert or play into the Western gaze
I wouldn't, but just because I'm not a fan of writing essays and doing close readings of essays.
